chatgpt_double_star.new_statement: Government should make sure everyone can get essential care regardless of income or job status, with an emphasis on primary, preventive, emergency, and behavioral health services and strong protections against medical debt. It should set and enforce clear rules on prices, quality, billing, and data interoperability, while paying in ways that reward outcomes and reduce waste. Care can be delivered through a mix of public programs and regulated private and nonprofit plans, with room for supplemental coverage and patient choice as long as universal access and fiscal sustainability are maintained.

chatgpt_double_star_rankings.new_statement: Government should guarantee a universal, affordable baseline of essential care—especially preventive, primary, emergency, chronic, and mental-health services—so no one faces financial ruin or delayed treatment. That public floor should be funded transparently and managed with strong accountability, evidence-based standards, price transparency, and cost controls to reduce waste and protect taxpayers. Private and community providers should deliver care through flexible local partnerships, with room for supplemental private coverage and innovation as long as it does not undermine universal access or quality.

chatgpt_double_star_personas.new_statement: Government should ensure every resident can access a clearly defined, affordable core of essential healthcare—especially preventive, primary, emergency, mental-health, and chronic-care services—so no one is pushed into medical bankruptcy. To earn trust across viewpoints, the program should use transparent funding, strong anti-fraud measures, and evidence-based cost controls with clear quality standards and simple administration. Private and employer coverage should remain available for supplemental benefits and competing delivery models, as long as they meet basic consumer protections and do not undermine universal access. Federal standards paired with state and local flexibility can improve rural access, strengthen the healthcare workforce, and support community-based care.
